note.p: Research Field: Atmospheric and atomic physics

Education: Greenheyes Collegiate School Manchester; BSc (Owens College, Manchester); gained an entrance scholarship to Sidney Sussex College Cambridge,(1888) and graduated 1892. MA (Cantab); BSc (Vict)

Career: Appointed James Clerk Maxwell Scholar at the Cavendish Laboratory (1895) and published his first work on the cloud chamber; develops his work on behaviours of ions as condensation nuclei (1893-1898); appointed by Meteorological Research Council to conduct research on atmospheric electricity (from 1899); Fellow, Sidney Sussex College (1900); appointed Reader in Electrical Meteorology (1918); published his two landmark illustrated papers on the tracks of electrons (1923); Jacksonian Professor of Natural Philosophy, Cambridge (1925-1934)
Awarded Honorary LL.D. from University of Aberdeen (1924)

Medals/Prizes: Hughes Medal 1911; Royal Medal 1922; Copley Medal 1935; Nobel Prize (Physics) 1927 with Arthur Holly Compton (1892-1962) for his work on the Wilson cloud chamber, which made the paths of electically charged particles visible by condensation of vapour.
Obituaries: Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society 1960 vol 6 pp 269-295, plate, by P M S Blackett
References: P I Dee and T W Wormell, 'An Index to C T R Wilson's Laboratory Records and Notebooks in the Library of the Royal Society' in NR 1963 vol 18 pp 54-66
C T R Wilson, 'Reminiscences of My Early Years' in NR 1959 vol 14 pp 163-173, plate
Wilfried Schroder and Karl-Heinrich Wiederkehr, 'Johann Kiessling, the Krakatoa event and the development of atmospheric optics after 1883' in NR 2000 vol 54 pp249-258
